Hint: the real solution is an integer between -6 and 6. Also the rational root theorem places additional constraints on possible real solutions. Descarte’s rule of signs can also help eliminate possibilities.

• Guess that (x+1)(x+1) is a factor:
    1 -11 60 72
    -1 -1 12 -72
    1 -12 72 0
    Notice, the remainder is 0, so the guess was good! So, we rephrase the original equation into a semi-factored form.(x+1)(x2−12x+72)=0(x+1)(x^2-12x+72)=0 I would recommend using quadratic formula to determine the complex roots.a=1a=1 b=−12b=-12 c=72c=72

Plug numbers into the quadratic formula.

x=−(−12)±(−12)2−4(1)(72)2(1)x = \frac{-(-12)\pm\sqrt{(-12)^2-4(1)(72)}}{2(1)}

Simplify.

x=12±−1442x = \frac{12 \pm \sqrt{-144}}{2}

x=12±12i2x = \frac{12 \pm 12i}{2}

x=6+6iORx=6−6ix = 6+6i ~~~~~~~~\text{OR}~~~~~~~~ x=6-6i

We could rewrite the original equation in fully factored form.

(x−(−1))⋅(x−(6−6i))⋅(x−(6+6i))=0\Big(x-(-1)\Big)\cdot\Big(x-(6-6i)\Big)\cdot\Big(x-(6+6i)\Big)~~=~~0

The solutions are: x=−1x = -1 x=6−6ix = 6-6i x=6+6ix = 6+6i
